repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
Issues were:
1. DefNode.has_fused_arguments was set too early (before
locals/annotations) were evalutated, so function was not treated
as fused.
2. When re-evaluating the specializations of the fused function
it was treated as a redefinition because the locals/annotation was
reapplied over the specialized type.

comment_data.body: [Still not](https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/3372#discussion_r382061610) a friend of `getattr()`, in cases like this. What's the reason why there would be no `name`? (That's completely unclear from this use of `getattr()`.)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -877,7 +877,8 @@ def analyse(self, env, nonempty=0, is_self_arg=False):
 
             # inject type declaration from annotations
             # this is called without 'env' by AdjustDefByDirectives transform before declaration analysis
-            if self.annotation and env and env.directives['annotation_typing'] and self.base_type.name is None:
+            if (self.annotation and env and env.directives['annotation_typing']
+                    and getattr(self.base_type, "name", None) is None):

comment_data.body:
Isn't this just `pass`? Why reassign `.type` here?
I would rather avoid the assignment below in this case. Or use `pass` with a comment, in case there could be other special cases to handle in the future.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1678,6 +1679,8 @@ def align_argument_type(self, env, arg):
             return arg
         if other_type is None:
             error(type_node.pos, "Not a type")
+        elif other_type.is_fused and any(orig_type.same_as(t) for t in other_type.types):
+            arg.type = orig_type  # use specialized rather than fused type

comment_data.body: Wouldn't a string type name make this available in older Py3 versions?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,39 @@
+# mode: run
+# tag: fused,
+# tag: pure3.7
+
+#cython: annotation_typing=True
+
+from __future__ import annotations
+
+import cython
+
+class TestCls:
+    def func1(self, arg: NotInPy):

comment_data.body: We only have a single line of tags in other test files, I think.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,39 @@
+# mode: run
+# tag: fused,
+# tag: pure3.7

comment_data.body: There is also a second case that might be worth testing here: a fused type that is declared directly in the `.py` file with `cython.fused_type()`. IIRC, that should use different code paths for applying the types. (If that fails, though, it's ok to fix it in a separate PR.)

`self.base_type` should apparently be a subclass of [`CBaseTypeNode`](https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/master/Cython/Compiler/Nodes.py#L927) (which doesn't have an attribute `name`). In practice it seems to be one of `CSimpleBaseTypeNode` (which has an attribute `name`), or `CAnalysedBaseTypeNode` (which doesn't actually inherit from `CBaseTypeNode`, and which doesn't have an attribute `name`).

`getattr` seemed the easiest way out of that mess, but if you want to propose an alternative I'd be happy to use it instead.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -877,7 +877,8 @@ def analyse(self, env, nonempty=0, is_self_arg=False):
 
             # inject type declaration from annotations
             # this is called without 'env' by AdjustDefByDirectives transform before declaration analysis
-            if self.annotation and env and env.directives['annotation_typing'] and self.base_type.name is None:
+            if (self.annotation and env and env.directives['annotation_typing']
+                    and getattr(self.base_type, "name", None) is None):

comment_data.body: Yes - I think this is just `pass`. I'll take it out.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1678,6 +1679,8 @@ def align_argument_type(self, env, arg):
             return arg
         if other_type is None:
             error(type_node.pos, "Not a type")
+        elif other_type.is_fused and any(orig_type.same_as(t) for t in other_type.types):
+            arg.type = orig_type  # use specialized rather than fused type

comment_data.body: A string type name didn't work. It was what I originally tried. I'll try to see if I can work out why before revising this though.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,39 @@
+# mode: run
+# tag: fused,
+# tag: pure3.7
+
+#cython: annotation_typing=True
+
+from __future__ import annotations
+
+import cython
+
+class TestCls:
+    def func1(self, arg: NotInPy):

comment_data.body: I can't say right now if there are any cases where we would like to disallow it, but I guess we can just wait until a user finds one and complains. :)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1434,11 +1434,7 @@ def _analyse_name_as_type(name, pos, env):
         return type
 
     global_entry = env.global_scope().lookup(name)
-    if global_entry and global_entry.type and (
-            global_entry.type.is_extension_type
-            or global_entry.type.is_struct_or_union
-            or global_entry.type.is_builtin_type
-            or global_entry.type.is_cpp_class):
+    if global_entry and global_entry.is_type and global_entry.type:

comment_data.body: See? You actually know a lot more about the underlying behaviour than the code originally allowed readers to infer. Thanks for the comment.
comment_data.diff_hunk:

-            if self.annotation and env and env.directives['annotation_typing'] and self.base_type.name is None:

+                    and getattr(self.base_type, "name", None) is None):

commit.message:
Fused arguments specified by annotation or locals

Issues were:
1. DefNode.has_fused_arguments was set too early (before
locals/annotations) were evalutated, so function was not treated
as fused.
2. When re-evaluating the specializations of the fused function
it was treated as a redefinition because the locals/annotation was
reapplied over the specialized type.

Changes from review

Including annotation as string (required changes to
StringNode.analyse_as_type), and extra tests for fused type defined
as cython.fused_type in the Py file

Removed unncessary from __future__ in test

Causing it to fail on pure Python 3.0-3.6

title: Fused arguments specified by annotation or locals
